lines.text: Do you want me to do it for you?
Yes.
You're supposed to say no.
[Jaime is using girlfriends as the variables in an algebraic equation]
Can you have negative girlfriends?
No, only negative boyfriends. Forgive us, for we know not what we do.

your name and your complexion. Because of those two strikes, there are some people in this world who will assume that you know less than you do. *Math* is the great equalizer... When you go for a job, the person giving you that job will not want to hear your problems; ergo, neither do I. You're going to work harder here than you've ever worked anywhere else. And the only thing I ask from you is *ganas.* *Desire.*
[Passing one boy, he ruffles up the student's hair]
And maybe a haircut.
[Everyone laughs]
If you don't have the *ganas,* I will give it to you because I'm an expert.
How'd you do it?
I got the test ahead of time and passed it out to all the others?
How did you get it?
The Mailman
[pause]
I strangled him and his body's decomposing in my locker.
It's not that they're stupid, it's just they don't know anything.
If we discuss sex, I have to give sex for homework.
Hey, Kemo, you should be proud of me, man! I'm the first dude here. What's calcoolus?
You think you got it, Johnny? Think you have the answer?
Juan is X, Carlos is Y, Pedro is X + Y. Is Pedro bisexual or straight?
Sometimes I worry about you.

...Did you know that neither the Greeks nor the Romans were capable of using the concept of zero? It was your ancestors, the Mayans, who first contemplated the zero. The absence of value. True story. You *burros* have math in your blood... A negative times a negative equals a positive. Why?
[the whole class looks at him blankly; he sighs deeply and shakes his head]
We're gonna need a lot of Kleenexes - there's gonna be a lot of bloodshed.
You only see the turn, you don't see the road ahead.
Lots of stars up there, Homey. Not too polluted.

The stars aren't really there, ese. No, what you're looking at is where they used to be, man. It takes the light a thousand years to reach the Earth. You know, for all we know, they burned out a long time ago, man. God pulled the plug on us. He didn't tell nobody.
The stars are out there, homeboy. I don't care what you say.
[Escalante is eating in the Delgado family's restaurant, speaking with them about Ana's decision to drop out of Garfield High]
She'll just get fat, waste her life away in your restaurant. You have to understand - she's a top student.
I started washing dishes for a nickel an hour. Now I own this place. Did *I* waste *my* life?
I washed dishes, too, when I first came to this country.
Good! Why don't you put on an apron and give us a hand?
...Ana could go to college, come back, and teach you how to run this place.

[He tears up the tab for Jaime's dinner]
Professor Escalante, I don't want your money. And I don't need your business.

[He reaches into his wallet, dropping the money on the table anyway]
Tip, for Ana. By the way, I notice you put hot chilies in your dip to sell extra beer - don't you?
[Angel doesn't want anyone to see him carrying books around]
Wouldn't want anyone thinking you're intelligent, would you?
You're like a blind man in a dark room looking for a black cat that isn't there!
Hey, what you got?
I got a core.
You owe me a hundred percent. And I'll see you in the People's Court.

[after confronting the ETS investigators]
You know what kills me... it's that they lost the confidence in the system they're now finally qualified to be a part of. I don't know why I'm losing sleep over this. I don't need it. I could be making more money, with less hours, and have people treat me with respect.
Respect? Jaime, those kids love you.
Nobody has the right to accuse me of racism.
[shouting]
Nobody has the right to accuse me of racism.
I don't need no math. I got a solar calculator with my dozen donuts.
Now you got a ticket to watch the show
There is two kinds of racism, Mr. Escalante. Judging a group because they are a minority, and *not* judging a group because they are a minority.
[last lines]
I want the original scores reinstated.

[while Escalante is cooking dinner]
Why don't we order out?
[Escalante looks at him incredulously]
I'm kidding, man!

[struggling with a calculus problem]
Don't laugh!
How can we laugh? You're breaking our hearts.
...Just don't ever let her know that you dig her. That's, like, the worst thing you can do with a woman.
Go to woodshop and make yourself a shoeshine box. You're gonna need it.

You the man, you know? Why don't you put them in college, huh? So dumb taco benders like me can pick their vegetables for them, collect their garbage, clip their poodles' toenails. I may be a sinner, but I'm willing to pay for my sins.
Right. See you at three.
I got more bad news for you, *profe.* I know this is really gonna trip you out, but... I forgot my pencil.
[Ana produces a pencil for him]
Tough guys don't do math. Tough guys fry chicken for a living.
You're worried that we'll screw up royally tomorrow, aren't you?
Tomorrow's another day. I'm worried you're gonna screw up the rest of your lives.
[Gang leader enters classroom, trailed by two henchmen]
Are your friends auditing?
I audited them to come with me.
Yeah, I have the same answer as gordita.
Don't call me gordita, pendejo.
My kids could teach you a thing or two, Johnny.

[about Claudia]
This girl's gotta do some work from the neck up. We're going to have to stay late again. Of course you know, we have pizza because they deliver. We can get fried chicken, hamburgers with cheese. We'll need donations. No, really, you owe me money anyway. You don't deserve the grades you're getting.
[Claudia gets up and leaves]
Where are you going? Late for another date? She's got more boyfriends than Elizabeth Taylor.
I don't appreciate you using my personal life to entertain this class.
Kemo, we're seniors. This is our year to slack off
Those scores would have never been questioned if my kids did not have Spanish surnames and come from barrio schools. You know that.
Do you think the students cheated?
Mr. Escalante, you put these kids under an awful lot of pressure. They would have gone to any lengths to please you.
You didn't answer my question.

Well... every night when I go to bed, I watch the television news. I see a lot of people go on trial. They always deny everything, or their lawyers say they were insane at the time. A lot of them get off. But I believe that most people who get caught today are guilty. Don't you?

[angrily]
Yup. I know what you mean.

[Angel reaches for a pen in Jaime's shirt pocket; Jaime grabs his wrist]
I wouldn't do that if I was you. Might lose a finger and won't be able to count to ten.
Pump gas.
Students will rise to the level of expectation, Senor Molina.
Your husband comes into my restaurant, eats... and he insults me!
Excuse my husband, Mr. Delgado. He just wants what's best for Ana.
She can go to college, come back, teach you how to run the place.
[he leaves money on the table]
Professor...
[shoves the money back]
I don't want your money. And I don't need your business.
Skip it. Tip.
Calculus was not made to be easy. It already is.

[Escalante is driving Pancho's car]
Kemo, I don't wanna let you down but the money I'd be making'll buy me a new Trans Am.
No one cruise through life, Pancho. Wouldn't you rather be designing these things than repairing them? Can't even do that, things got fuel injection -
[grinds gears]
Kemo, you're gonna strip my gears, man!
Don't panic, Johnny, just watch out for the other guy -
[grinds gears again]
Right or left?
GO RIGHT! GO RIGHT!
[Kemo turns right, screams to halt in front of a dead end]
All you can see is the turn, don't see the road ahead...
I may have made a mistake.
Either I teach calculus next year, or have a good day.
Well, if this man can dictate terms to us, I see no reason for me to continue as department chair.

[spontaneously resigning as department chair]
Have a good day.
